text.p: Georgia-Pacific Corp. Thursday reported higher earnings for the latest quarter, citing benefits from its cost-cutting plans, but the pulp and paper business again struggled.

The company said it earned $27 million, or 30 cents a share, in the second quarter, up from earnings of $5 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier. Last year's quarter included a $74 million charge for a voluntary early retirement programme.
Sales in the latest quarter were flat at $3.3 billion.
Georgia-Pacific said its overhead costs shrank by $66 million from a year ago due to its cost-reduction efforts, but its pulp and paper results were hurt by lower prices.
The pulp and paper unit's operating profits dropped to $12 million from $33 million a year ago.
The building products' division did better, with operating profits jumping to $203 million from $141 million.
Georgia-Pacific's stock was up 69 cents at $93 on the New York Stock Exchange.
